ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a deeper understanding of how and why human civilization evolved, especially those that developed in the Fertile Crescent and Egypt.

Learned about ancient civilizations and how they grew/changed/fell with respect to the climate. Also learned about the history of social structures,  the development of empires, and some interesting archaeology stuff.

The course material is fascinating. Professor Weiss is clearly very knowledgeable and experienced in his field and dives deeper into history students may have touched on in high school. I found myself very interested in the course readings and the films we watched.
Thinking critically about historic events not just as distinct entities, but as a progressive sequence. Thinking how modern events relate to empires at the dawn of civilization.

I definitely learned a lot about ancient history through this course. Specifically, I learned about the climate of the ancient world and how that climate affected ancient civilization. I also think that we learned a lot about modern archaeological research, debates within the archaeological community, and how to best read archaeological research papers.
This class expanded my knowledge in the field of archeology. I learned a bunch of important methods for dating artifacts and events.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I cannot stress this enough, but this course was amazing!!!! On top of having a light workload in comparison to most other classes, the topics covered in the class are absolutely fascinating. Not only do you get insights into the historical/archaeological record, but most classes are punctuated by Professor Weisss stories from his digs in Northern Iraq.

The strength was the professor's passion for the material. He was very knowledgable and spoke extensively about his work and how it relates to what we know today about these civilizations. The biggest weakness was a complete lack of discussion. I was hoping for discussion-based class and it was instead more of a lecture with the professor asking occasional questions. There was no discussion between students during class and no opportunity for it. The other biggest issue was the repetitiveness of the class. There were a few instances where entire lectures felt like they were repeated.

Strengths--Professor Weiss is very knowledgeable and is very passionate about the course material.
Weaknesses--Though the class is structured like a seminar, I wish students were prompted for input more often.

Strengths - very interesting content
WeK eases - not conducive to class discussion

I would say that some strengths of the course were that the workload was relatively light and the content itself was very interesting. Some weaknesses were that there was minimal discussion in class since the class was taught almost in a lecture format. It was also challenging to know what you're grade was during the semester because 1/3 of the grade was the midterm, 1/3 was the final, and 1/3 was class participation (which was difficult to assess). I think perhaps some more class-wide discussions about the content and its implications could be very rewarding and improve the course, but I still think the class was good overall.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You are doing yourself a disservice by NOT taking this class. This is a hidden GEM!!! Professor Weiss is amazing and so engaging, the material is intellectually stimulating, and it doesnt have all that much work. Everyone should be putting this class at the top of their list!
I would not recommend this if you're looking for an engaging seminar/discussion class. The content itself was interesting but I found the format of the class incredibly dull.
I would recommend this course to another student as it was a fascinating exploration of the origins of civilization as well as the modern history (WW1-present) of the region of Mesopotamia.

Probably. This class seems like a banner for the first-year seminar program. I'm not sure if anyone in the class took it to major in NELC, but we were all exposed to a line of study that is different from our own. The class was a little messy at times, and sometimes instructions were a bit unclear. However, I found myself engaged in it class after class.
Yes - but not if you are really looking for a seminar. Much more like a small lecture.

I would recommend this course to another student. Even though there are some weaknesses, I think the topic was fascinating and the workload was light. I think this a good class for both history majors who want to explore Mesopotamian history in greater depth later in college and other students who just want to take an interesting class about history.
Yes. Unique knowledge, a very experienced professor.
